title: PTD Today — Media

items.title: How AI Empowers Artists. Watch the full episode on our channel now.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this film accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award–winning podcast Where the Internet Lives and looks at the unseen world of data centers through the theme "How AI Empowers Artists." It ties AI and creativity to data and infrastructure, aiming to illuminate connections between artistic AI uses and the data centers that support them.
bullets: Film accompanies Season 5 of the podcast Where the Internet Lives.
Focuses on the unseen world of data centers.
Explores the theme: How AI empowers artists.
Produced by Google; tagged #WhereTheInternetLives #AI #Data #Creativity.
No transcript provided in the supplied content.
takeaways: If the episode highlights AI-driven creative workflows, expect increased compute, storage, and networking demands that affect capacity planning and energy use.
Greater visibility into data center roles for creative AI underscores the importance of efficiency measures (PUE, cooling) and renewable procurement to manage operational carbon and costs.
Variable, bursty artist workloads imply value in flexible capacity strategies—scalable compute, demand-response participation, and storage tiering.
Scaling AI-supporting hardware should factor hardware lifecycles and critical-minerals sourcing / recycling risks when planning procurement and decommissioning.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno (Product Manager, Cloud Networking at Google) outlines how networking must evolve to support AI inference by using AI-aware routing, specialized load balancing, and service extensions to optimize GPU utilization, latency, and governance. Google Cloud’s approach (GKE Inference Gateway + Cloud Load Balancing + GKE) leverages inference-specific metrics and features such as KV cache utilization, prefix caching, body-based routing and network-inserted guardrails to reduce cold starts, lower costs, and sanitize traffic before it reaches models.
bullets: Problem: traditional networking and metrics (CPU-based, round-robin LB) miss GPU saturation and send traffic to congested replicas, causing latency and inefficiency.
Key solution: GKE Inference Gateway + AI-aware load balancing that uses inference metrics (e.g., KV cache utilization, queue depth) to stack-rank least-loaded replicas.
Performance features: prefix cache shadowing to reuse prefill work, body-based routing for model identification, and LoRA adapter awareness to match requests to appropriate replicas.
Security/governance: Service Extensions enable inserting API management and AI guardrails at the network layer to sanitize prompts/responses and drop invalid requests before consuming GPU cycles.
Products mentioned: GKE Inference Gateway, Cloud Load Balancing, Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE).
takeaways: Network-aware scheduling and inference metrics can materially increase GPU saturation—reducing idle GPU power draw and improving compute efficiency for data centers.
Edge guardrails that block invalid or out-of-policy prompts before model invocation cut wasted GPU runtime and associated energy/cooling costs.
Prefix caching and prefill reuse smooth peak GPU demand (fewer cold starts), helping with capacity planning and potentially lowering required peak power provisioning.
Adopting inference-specific telemetry in load balancers is essential for accurate capacity management and for avoiding misleading CPU-based indicators when planning rack-level power and cooling.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this short clip showcases the open-world martial arts RPG "Where Winds Meet" running with NVIDIA features enabled. It specifically highlights DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation and #RTXOn, with footage credited to @DigitalDreamsyt.
bullets: Open-world martial arts RPG: Where Winds Meet.
Highlights NVIDIA DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation.
Promoted with #RTXOn to indicate ray-tracing/RTX tech in use.
Video credit: @DigitalDreamsyt.
No transcript available — description is brief.
takeaways: DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation implies potential for higher rendering throughput per GPU, which could reduce energy-per-frame if broadly adopted.
Wider use of RTX/DLSS features in games and cloud-streamed titles may increase demand for GPU-equipped servers and associated data center power capacity.
Scaling cloud/edge game streaming with advanced frame-generation tech could affect peak power provisioning and cooling requirements for hosting facilities.
Broader adoption of advanced GPUs can influence procurement planning and may increase pressure on supply chains for GPUs and related critical minerals.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video stresses that the steam turbine rotor is the backbone of a steam plant’s reliability and that it’s critical to anticipate an aging rotor’s remaining life and determine appropriate next steps. GE Vernova points viewers to a rotor end-of-life resource and positions itself as leading energy electrification and decarbonization.
bullets: Highlights importance of forecasting remaining life for aging steam turbine rotors.
Focus on defining ‘what to do next’ when rotor end-of-life approaches (options implied).
Directs viewers to a GE Vernova rotor EOL resource for more information.
GE Vernova branding and channel subscription/social links included; company mission noted.
takeaways: For grid and data-center operators, proactively assessing rotor remaining life reduces risk of unplanned outages and supports reliability commitments.
Integrate rotor EOL timing into maintenance schedules, spare-parts inventory, and capacity planning (including backup/renewables strategies).
Evaluate trade-offs between life-extension/repair and replacement based on downtime, cost, and long-term asset plans.
Leverage vendor resources (e.g., GE Vernova’s rotor EOL guidance) to inform technical assessments and procurement/asset-management decisions.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the KPMG ON AIR episode reviews how the luxury goods market is changing—shifting toward experiences, personalization and “affordable luxury,” with stronger ESG expectations and new buyer cohorts like Gen Z. Guests also compare Poland’s growing but fragmented market to global trends and discuss luxury in hospitality, art, tourism and the potential role of AI, craftsmanship and human experience going forward.
bullets: Global trends: luxury fatigue, but 2% of richest clients still drive ~40% of market.
Shift from ownership to experiences—personalization and exclusive customer journeys emphasized.
Rise of 'affordable luxury' and aspirational buyers; Gen Z prefers experiences over possessions.
Growing ESG focus: responsible materials (e.g., eco-leathers) and certification pressures.
Poland-specific notes: market growing yet fragmented; opportunities in hotels, spas, tourism, art; future role for AI alongside craft and human touch.
takeaways: AI and personalization trends imply higher digital service demand—plan data‑center capacity, power and cooling for increased compute and low‑latency services.
Expansion of luxury hotels, spas and premium tourism in Poland could raise local peak electrical loads—consider resilience, on‑site generation and energy storage for critical facilities.

Stronger ESG and certification expectations point to growing demand for renewable energy procurement and supply‑chain transparency; traceability may extend to critical‑minerals sourcing for certain luxury goods.
Concentration of high‑value customers and premium retail/residential projects increases need for reliable backup power, power quality and secure connectivity in premium locations.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, PJM Interconnection has made reliability its priority since 1927 and the video explains how PJM works to keep electricity available when customers need it. The content is framed around PJM's longstanding mission to ensure dependable power delivery across its footprint.
bullets: PJM has prioritized reliability since 1927.
The video focuses on how PJM works to make sure electricity is there when needed.
Emphasis is on PJM’s role in maintaining dependable power delivery.
Intended to inform viewers about PJM’s operational mission.
Target audience includes stakeholders dependent on consistent grid service.
takeaways: For grid planners and substations: align maintenance and contingency plans with PJM’s reliability expectations and communications.
For data center operators: maintain active coordination with PJM and build on-site resilience (backup generation/UPS) to complement regional reliability.
For renewables and storage developers: engage early with PJM interconnection and operational processes to ensure reliable integration.
For asset owners: factor PJM’s reliability focus into capacity planning and outage readiness.
Keep channels open with the regional operator to anticipate system conditions and operational guidance.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy frames grid modernization as a balance of reliability, flexibility and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. The company emphasizes digital technologies as central to improving grid stability, reducing downtime, and optimizing performance across power systems.
bullets: Grid modernization must balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency while growing capacity for the energy transition.
Digital technologies are positioned as core to next‑generation power systems.
Digital tools aim to improve grid stability and reduce downtime.
Performance optimization is targeted at every level of the power system.
Capacity expansion is linked to enabling the broader energy transition.
takeaways: Evaluate digital grid solutions to enhance uptime and operational performance for substations and feeder networks.
Prioritize capacity planning that supports increased renewable and storage integration as part of the energy transition.
Target technologies that specifically improve stability and reduce downtime to protect critical loads like data centers.
Assess end‑to‑end digital capabilities (operations, analytics, control) to optimize performance across system layers.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy frames industrial resilience around energy efficiency, process optimization and digital integration. The company positions itself as a partner that builds smarter systems to boost productivity, reliability and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Resilience rests on energy efficiency, process optimization and digital integration.
Hitachi Energy collaborates with customers and partners to deliver smarter systems.
Goals emphasized: improved productivity, greater reliability, and enhanced sustainability.
Focus is operational — applying technology and partnership across industrial operations.
takeaways: Prioritize energy-efficiency and process-optimization initiatives to strengthen operational resilience and reduce operating risk.
Invest in digital integration (analytics, control and automation) to improve reliability and productivity across substations, plants and data centers.
Consider partnering with experienced suppliers for integrated solutions that align reliability and sustainability goals.
Track sustainability outcomes alongside uptime and performance when evaluating infrastructure upgrades or vendor solutions.
